A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraically closed field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To understand whether the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of an algebraically closed field, we need to analyze the components of the definition of an algebraically closed field:

1. A field $K$ is a set with additional structure (operations of addition and multiplication that satisfy certain axioms).
2. The definition of an algebraically closed field involves the concept of polynomials $f$ in $K[X]$, where $K[X]$ denotes the set of all polynomials with coefficients in $K$. This implies that $K[X]$ is also a set, specifically a set of polynomials.
3. The definition states that every nonconstant polynomial $f$ in $K[X]$ must decompose into linear factors within $K[X]$. This decomposition implies a collection of factors and zeros, each of which is an element of the set $K$.
